content:
That's a great plan! Personalizing your follow-up emails and mentioning specific details from your conversations will help keep you top of mind and show that you're genuinely interested in pursuing potential collaborations.

By asking Dr. Smith to introduce you to potential partners in the industry, you're taking a proactive step towards exploring new opportunities. And by asking to meet up for coffee, you're showing that you value his time and expertise, and that you're willing to invest in building a relationship.

Similarly, sending over the contracts to the lawyer and asking for their feedback and suggestions demonstrates that you're serious about getting your startup's legal affairs in order. And by asking if they know of any other resources or connections that could be helpful, you're showing that you're open to learning and growing.

Remember to be respectful of people's time and expertise, and don't be pushy or aggressive in your follow-up communications. You want to build relationships, not try to force opportunities that aren't a good fit.

Also, be sure to keep track of your follow-up communications and any subsequent meetings or conversations. You can use a CRM (customer relationship management) tool or simply a spreadsheet to keep notes and reminders about your interactions with each connection.

Overall, it sounds like you're taking a thoughtful and strategic approach to following up with your new connections. Keep up the good work, and I'm sure you'll see some valuable opportunities emerge from these connections!
